text: Psalm 49
Wealth and the Fate of the Wicked

For the \add music\add* director. Of the sons of Korah. A psalm.\f + \fr Ps 49 \ft The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one \f*
Hear this, all \add you\add* peoples;
give ear, all \add you\add* inhabitants of \add the\add* world,
both low and high,
rich and poor together.
My mouth will speak wisdom,
and the meditation of my heart \add will be\add* understanding.
I will incline my ear to a proverb;
I will ⸤propound⸥\f + \fr 49:4 \ft Literally “open” \f* my riddle on a lyre.
Why should I fear in ⸤times of calamity⸥,\f + \fr 49:5 \ft Literally “the days of evil” \f*
\add when\add* iniquity surrounds me at my heels,
those who trust their wealth
and boast about the abundance of their riches?
Surely a man cannot redeem a brother.
He cannot give to God his ransom
(since\f + \fr 49:8 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* the redemption price for their life is costly
and it always fails),
so that he may stay alive forever
\add and\add* not see the pit.
For he sees \add that\add* the wise die,
together \add with the\add* fool and brute they perish,
and leave their wealth to the next \add generation\add*.
Within them \add they think\add* their houses \add are\add* forever,
their dwelling places from generation to generation.
They ⸤name⸥\f + \fr 49:11 \ft Literally “call” \f* \add their\add* lands by their \add own\add* names.
But man cannot continue in \add his\add* pomp.
He is like the beasts \add that\add* perish.
This \add is\add* the journey\f + \fr 49:13 \ft Hebrew “way” \f* \add of those who\add* have foolish \add confidence\add*,
and those after them \add who\add* accept their sayings. \qs Selah\qs*
Like sheep they are destined to Sheol;
death will shepherd them.
But the upright will rule over them in the morning,
and their forms \add will be for\add* Sheol to consume,
\add far from\add* his lofty abode.
Surely God will ransom my life
from the ⸤power⸥\f + \fr 49:15 \ft Literally “hand” \f* of Sheol,
because he will receive me. \qs Selah\qs*
Do not fear when a man becomes rich,
when the wealth\f + \fr 49:16 \ft Or “honor” \f* of his house increases,
because when he dies he will not take \add away\add* any \add of it\add*.
His wealth will not follow down after him.
Though he congratulated his soul while he was living
—and \add people\add* will praise you when you do well for yourself—
it\f + \fr 49:19 \ft That is, his soul \f* will go to the generation of his fathers.
Never will they see light.
Humankind in \add its\add* pomp, but does not understand,
is like the beasts \add that\add* perish.
